g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute

high costs, legal barriers), policy would be needed make low carbon actions more attractive, or to make
high carbon actions less attractive. As people generally face multiple barriers for change, combinations
of policies would be more ef
Financial incentives can motivate mitigation actions
Maki et al. 2016; Bolderdijk et al. 2011)
countries, more residential solar PV were installed after the introduction of favo
tariffs, federal income tax credits, and net metering
Similarly, a subsidy promoted the installation of solar water heaters in
financial incentives may underperform expectations when other factors are overlooked. For example,
people may not respond to financial incentives when they do not trust the organization sponsoring the
program or when it takes t
oo much effort to receive the incentive
Financial incentives are more effective if combined with strategies addressing non
r seems less effective than emphasizing social
or benefits of actions for people (e.g., public health, comfort) and the
(Asensio and Delmas 2015, 2016; Schwartz et al. 2015; Ossokina 2020; Bolderd
Financial appeals may have limited effects because they reduce people’s focus on environmental
consequences, weaken intrinsic motivation to engage in mitigation actions, provide a license to pollute
(Agrawal et al. 2015; Bolderdijk and Steg 2015; Schwartz et al. 2015)
Providing information on the causes and consequences of climate change or on effective mitigation
actions increases people’s knowledge and awareness, but generally does not promote mitigation actions
representations of climate change may inhibi
t action when they make people feel helpless
feedback can promote energy savings, load shifting
in electricity use and sustainable travel, particularly when framed in terms of losses rather than gains
(Gonzales et al. 1988; Wolak 2011; Bradley et al. 2016; Bager and Mundaca 2017)
targeted information at the point of decision can promote action
more effective when delivered by a trusted so
, and when tailored to actors’ personal situation
msma and Steg 2014; van den Broek et al. 2017; Daamen
et al. 2001; Wolsko et al. 2016; Bolderdijk et al. 2013)
This explains why home energy audits promoted
Energy use feedback can promote energy saving behavio
2011; Fischer 2008; Karlin et al. 2015; Delmas et al. 2013; Zangheri et al. 2019)
time or immediately after the action so that people learn
Delmas et al. 2013; Abrahamse et al. 2005;

ncourage energy savings as they immediately make sense and hardly
require users’ conscious attention. Feedback can make people aware of their previous mitigation
rs, which can strengthen their environmental self
identity, and motivate them to engag
other mitigation actions as well as to act in line with their self
